_header: Who hath that cunning by wisdom or prudence
_description: The deceitfulness of friendship — one 8-line stanza (ababbcbc)

BodRawD82.First Lines:
Wo hath þat Conyng by wysdam or prudenceto know whether his
                    frende be feynt or stable
BodRawD82.Last Lines:
Allas to say hit ys full lementableVnneth A man now may
                    truste his owne broþer
BodRawD82.Note:
A different (sixteeth to seventeenth-century) hand wrote ‘marke
                    thus well’ on the margin and copied the stanza changing the last line to:
                    ‘Deseaytis so great men trust not ther brother’.
BodRawD82.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope,
                        ed.  
             Secular Lyrics of the XIV and XV Centuries.
         2nd ed. Oxford: Clarendon, 1955: 101.
Luria,  Maxwell Sidney,  and  Richard L. Hoffman, eds.  
             Middle English Lyrics.
         New York: Norton, 1974: 119.
